The story behind Titan.

How a pharmacist with no data, no visibility, and no answers from the industry decided to build his own.

From CAPA to Invatech to Titan.
From one barcode label to thousands of pharmacies.

The full story ‚Äî in his own words.

posts.post_caption:
I've never told this story publicly before.

How Titan started. Why it started. What nearly killed it.

This isn't a corporate video. It's the truth.

It started with a problem I couldn't solve with any system on the market. So I built one.

From a kitchen table. From frustration. From one barcode label on 11th September 2001.

To the platform that now serves thousands of pharmacies.

This film is for every pharmacist who's ever felt the system was working against them.

You're the reason we exist.

üé¨ [YouTube link]

#Pharmacy #CommunityPharmacy #MyStory

posts.idea:
Short clip ‚Äî 35-45 seconds. Customer success story told by Sajid.

Sajid to camera telling Kanav/Winrosh Pharmacy story.

Quote: "One of the pharmacies that always sticks in my mind ‚Äî Kanav, Winrosh Pharmacy. Bought the pharmacy, did zero items. Within six, seven months, because he adopted a new way of working ‚Äî not only click to always fill ‚Äî he's grown to six, seven thousand items. Started from zero, chose the right digital partner, built a profitable and thriving business. And actually the community now has a thriving pharmacy that wasn't there before."

Edit notes:
- This is a customer story told through the sales leader's eyes ‚Äî different angle
- Lower third: Sajid Ramzan, Chief Sales Officer
- Could overlay Winrosh Pharmacy name/location if appropriate
- Warm, proud energy ‚Äî "I'm really proud to be part of it"
- Titan PMR logo end card
posts.post_caption:
Zero items. Brand new pharmacy. No history.

That was Kanav when he bought Winrosh Pharmacy.

Within six months, he'd adopted a completely new way of working. Click to always fill. Digital-first from day one.

Today? Six to seven thousand items. A profitable, thriving business.

And a community that finally has a pharmacy looking after them that wasn't there before.

These are the stories we hear all the time. And we're proud to be part of them.

Sajid Ramzan, Chief Sales Officer

#TitanPMR #PharmacyGrowth #CommunityPharmacy #NewPharmacy
posts.name: LEADERS_SajidKanavStory

posts.idea:
Short clip ‚Äî 20-30 seconds. Tech/innovation angle.

Wahid to camera.

Quote: "Technology in pharmacy has been very stagnant. What we've done with Titan is give a platform for our customers to really unlock the potential within their own businesses. With our AI capability, we're able to really unlock what a pharmacy is capable of doing ‚Äî Am I making money? Am I making profit? Am I servicing my patients correctly?"

Edit notes:
- Lower third: Wahid Muhammad, CTO
- The three questions at the end could appear as text overlays one by one
- Tech-forward energy
- Titan PMR logo end card
- Could pair with dashboard/AI feature B-roll
posts.post_caption:
"Am I making money? Am I making profit? Am I servicing my patients correctly?"

Every pharmacy owner has these questions. Most don't have a way to answer them.

Technology in pharmacy has been stagnant for too long. The systems were built for dispensing, not for running a business.

That's changing. With AI, we're giving pharmacies the ability to see exactly what's happening ‚Äî and act on it.

Not guesswork. Not gut feeling. Real answers.

Wahid Muhammad, CTO

#TitanPMR #PharmacyAI #PharmacyBusiness #Technology
posts.name: LEADERS_WahidUnlockAI

posts.post_caption:
Stefan's been on an electronic CD register for two years.

Separate system. Separate login. Manual entry that could introduce errors.

His take on Titan's CD register?

"Everything you'd expect from a CD log is there. But then you've got the Titan version of it ‚Äî which just makes it so much more efficient, accurate, and it's just easier and nicer to use."

Compliance isn't the differentiator. Every CD register does compliance.

The experience is the differentiator.

#TitanPMR #CDRegister #PharmacyCompliance

posts.idea:
7-slide carousel ‚Äî "Random Facts About Pharmacists" (Semrush's personality-building format)

CONCEPT: Each slide is a "fact" that's actually a relatable workplace truth. Self-deprecating humour builds brand affinity.

Slide 1: Photo/illustration of confused/exasperated pharmacist face
Large text: "Random facts you probably don't know about pharmacists ‚Üí"
Subtext: Titan PMR watermark small in corner

Slide 2: Large text, centred:
"Contrary to popular belief, pharmacists' job is ‚ú®patient care‚ú®"
Smaller text below: "Not counting, labelling, chasing GPs, fixing EPS errors, answering the same question 47 times..."

Slide 3: Large text:
"Statistically, 0% of pharmacists have ever had a lunch break that wasn't interrupted"

Slide 4: Large text:
"There have been no recorded instances of a pharmacist enjoying a 'quick chat' with a rep at 4:55pm"

Slide 5: Large text:
"The number of Post-it notes on their monitor is directly correlated to how close they are to burnout"

Slide 6: Large text:
"Pharmacists never recommend their own pharmacy to friends because they know what it's actually like back there"

Slide 7: Large text:
"It's scientifically proven that saying 'it's just a simple repeat' means it absolutely isn't"

Optional Slide 8: End card with Titan PMR logo
"We get it. üíä" / titanpmr.com

DESIGN NOTES:
- Bold, clean sans-serif typography
- Dark background throughout
- Large text that's readable at small sizes
- Subtle Titan watermark on each slide (not obnoxious)
- Consistent layout slide-to-slide
- Real human face on slide 1 creates connection

TONE: Self-deprecating, funny, insider knowledge. Shows Titan understands pharmacy life.

posts.idea:
Quote card ‚Äî single image

Layout: Dark navy background (#0d1117). Blue accent with slightly warmer tone (#3498db).

Hero quote in large white:
"That made staff more anxious."

Secondary quote below:
"100 lines coming rather than 10 lines coming. Laying 100 lines out before you book in. It was just absolute agony."

Attribution:
Jeet
Hub & Spoke Operator

Titan PMR logo: Bottom right.

Overall feel: Emotional. This isn't an efficiency post ‚Äî it's a wellbeing post. The word 'anxious' should land.
posts.post_caption:
Nobody talks about how stock processes make your team feel.

100 totes every morning instead of 10. Laying everything out. Checking. Reconciling. Two hours before you even start dispensing.

Jeet saw it:

"That made staff more anxious. It was just absolute agony."

Stock control isn't glamorous.

But the difference between a team that starts the day calm and a team that starts the day anxious?

That's everything.

#TitanPMR #StockControl #PharmacyTeam
posts.name: TITAN_StaffAnxiety_Jeet

Quote: "What's holding back is the fear. But if there's one thing we've proven time and time again is that change doesn't need to be scary. Yes, it's not gonna be the Maldives guys, I get it. But actually ‚Äî we've done this over 13, 1400 times. We're here to support you."

posts.post_caption:
"It's not gonna be the Maldives, guys. I get it."

Change is uncomfortable. Nobody's pretending otherwise.

But here's the thing ‚Äî we've done this over 1,400 times now. We know what the fear looks like. We know what's on the other side of it.

Implementation team. Support team. A process that works.

Short term pain, long term gain. Don't let fear hold you back.

Sajid Ramzan, Chief Sales Officer

#TitanPMR #PharmacyTransformation #ChangeManagement
posts.name: LEADERS_SajidChangeFear

posts.idea:
TikTok + LinkedIn clip

Clip: Tanzil's migration fear ‚Äî biggest concern was shifting the data. 70% ERD. Then the resolution: 3,000 items returned to spine, pulled onto Titan, on the queue.

Fear ‚Üí resolution in one clip.
posts.post_caption:
"My biggest concern moving across to Titan was ‚Äî how do we shift that data?"

Tanzil's pharmacy has one of the highest ERD percentages in England. 70%.

A phenomenal amount of data. Patients on repeat. All sat on the old system.

"Unless we're with Titan, we can't start to use the benefits without moving across. That was the first hurdle."

The result?

"3,000 items. Returned back onto the spine. Pulled them back onto Titan. We've now got that on the queue."

Done.

#TitanPMR #ERD #PharmacyMigration
posts.name: TITAN_HOD_HowDoWeShift3000_LI

Hero text in large white:
"The 25th of the month? Hang fire."

Jeet
Hub & Spoke Operator

Titan PMR logo: Bottom right.

Overall feel: Practical, shareable. This is a business tip, not a product post. Teal education colour signals 'save this.'
posts.post_caption:
A cash flow tip from a pharmacy running 40,000 items a month.

Jeet orders bulk lines every two weeks. Enough stock to last four.

"If it's the 25th of the month ‚Äî wait for five days before you order. You've already got two weeks worth of stock. Hang fire. Your cash flow is back to normal."

No software pitch. No feature list.

Just a pharmacist sharing what works.

Stock control isn't just about efficiency. It's about cash flow, confidence, and control.

#TitanPMR #PharmacyBusiness #CashFlow
posts.name: TITAN_CashFlowTrick_Jeet

posts.idea:
TikTok + LinkedIn clip

Clip: Sunil reframes the efficiency narrative. Natural wastage first, nice plateau, then growth. Larger business, more services, eventually MORE staffing.

Key: "This is not about just cutting out people."

Important message ‚Äî efficiency ‚â† job cuts.
posts.post_caption:
"This is not about just cutting out people."

Sunil runs 15 pharmacies. He's seen the efficiency gains first-hand.

But here's what actually happens:

"You get the natural wastage first when you change over a system. You can have those conversations with your team. You get a nice plateau."

"But that also then leads to growth. Which will increase staffing later."

"It means you're a much larger business everywhere. Doing more services. Doing all of those things."

Efficiency isn't the end.

It's the beginning.

#TitanPMR #PharmacyGrowth #PharmacyLeadership
posts.name: TITAN_HOD_NotCuttingPeople_LI

posts.post_caption:
No headline stat. No transformation claim.

Just honesty.

Riddhesh is rolling Titan across 16 pharmacies. One site has been live for two months. The rest? Last two weeks.

"We wouldn't have efficiency data yet. But they are taking to it really well."

"They're taking to it because they're not changing their workflow a lot."

Sometimes the most convincing testimonial isn't the big number.

It's catching someone mid-journey and hearing: "so far, so good."

#TitanPMR #Implementation #PharmacyTech

The fear was real. Move wrong and you disrupt thousands of patients.

The result?

3,000 items. Returned to the spine. Pulled back onto Titan.

"We've now got that on the queue."

The migration everyone said would be a nightmare. Done.

posts.post_caption:
Glen's been trialling batch dispensing across 7 branches.

The approach:

Single-item scripts first. Then double-item. Takes a large chunk of the daily bundle and processes them in batch.

Leaves the multi-item scripts to do one by one.

"It's working brilliantly."

Rolling out to the rest in the next few weeks.

Sometimes the smartest workflow change isn't a new feature.

It's using what you have differently.

(in muted #8b949e text, smaller)

Overall feel: Split comparison. Before is muted and small. After is bold and bright. The visual weight tells the story.
posts.post_caption:
Same inhaler. Ordered five times a week.

Two inhalers each time. Unpacked five mornings running. Laid out across the bench. Booked in separately.

Jeet changed one thing.

"25 inhalers gone in, booked in, and then it will just automatically reorder when we've reached our threshold."

"Staff don't have to lay out 25 different items. They're only laying out one item, 25 of them. Bang gone."

Once a fortnight instead of five times a week.

Stock control isn't glamorous. But the time it gives back is.

#TitanPMR #StockControl #PharmacyEfficiency

posts.idea:
Carousel Script (7 slides):
SLIDE 1 (Hook):

¬£158 MILLION CLAWBACK

Announced Dec 23rd.
Two days before Christmas.
Quietly slipped out.

Here's what you need to know.
SLIDE 2 (What is clawback?):

WHAT IS CLAWBACK?

The CPCF sets an "allowed profit envelope" for pharmacy.

If the sector's profit exceeds this level, the government claws it back the following year.

Sounds fair?

Keep reading.
SLIDE 3 (The unfair bit):

HERE'S THE CATCH

Clawback is calculated on the WHOLE INDUSTRY.

Not individual pharmacies.

If Boots makes excess profit, your pharmacy pays too.

Even if you're dispensing at a loss.
SLIDE 4 (The numbers):

THE REALITY

- ¬£16.8m clawed back per quarter
- Starting January 2026
- Applied to Category M and A drugs
- No individual assessment
- No appeals process
SLIDE 5 (The context):

THE BIGGER PICTURE

- 63% of pharmacies at risk of closure
- 248 closed in 2024 alone
- <10,000 remain in England
- 60% of owners took no salary in 2024
- ¬£2.6bn funding gap

And now: clawback.
SLIDE 6 (The quote):

"Pharmacies cannot plan, cannot invest, and are forced to dispense NHS medicines, day after day, often at a loss."

‚Äì Olivier Picard, NPA Chair
SLIDE 7 (CTA):

WHAT CAN YOU DO?

1. Understand your exposure
2. Track affected drug categories
3. Make the opaque visible

Titan can help.

titanpmr.com
Visual Brief:
‚Ä¢ Bold, stark design
‚Ä¢ Use red/warning colour accents
‚Ä¢ Large numbers on each slide
‚Ä¢ Clean, impactful typography
‚Ä¢ NPA quote on dedicated slide
‚Ä¢ Titan positioning subtle - focused on industry advocacy first
Notes:
‚Ä¢ This is "editorial/oracle" positioning - Titan being the voice of pharmacy
‚Ä¢ Pairs anger/injustice with practical help (reporting)
‚Ä¢ Follows the Mounjaro pricing post formula (timely + affects wallets + emotional)
‚Ä¢ Can link to a future "how Titan helps with clawback tracking" follow-up post

¬£158 million clawback.
Announced days before Christmas.
Calculated across the whole sector, not individual pharmacy performance.

Fair?

#CommunityPharmacy #CPCF #PharmacyFunding #TitanPMR

posts.idea:
INGLE IMAGE IDEA

(Pro-team, pro-community, neutral, no em dashes)**

Main Title

Technician supervision has begun.
Independents need workflows they can trust.

Subheadline

The 2026 changes divide opinion, but they all rely on one thing.
Safe and clear delegation.

‚∏ª

Visual Structure

Top Section: The Reality of the Divide

Two icons side by side:

Left Icon: Technician
Text:
Technicians supportive

Right Icon: Pharmacist
Text:
Pharmacists divided

Under both:
Independents carry the highest responsibility

‚∏ª

Middle Section: What the shift requires

posts.post_caption:
Technician supervision has already begun in UK pharmacy.

This legal change is a good thing because it reflects what already happens in most community pharmacies.

Pharmacists check the prescription, authorise it and seal the medication.

When the patient arrives, the handout is often completed by a trained member of the pharmacy team.

The new law simply formalises this workflow.

Titan supports this transition.
Titan‚Äôs workflow shows who checked the item and when it was authorised.
Titan Mobile adds clinical continuity by prompting the team with the pharmacist‚Äôs notes at handout, such as NMS reminders or key counselling points.

This gives pharmacies a safe, structured way to delegate handout while keeping the pharmacist‚Äôs clinical guidance in the process.

posts.post_caption:
Bulk nomination is undermining patient choice.

And it has created a completely unfair playing field.

Some PMR systems allow pharmacies to switch patients back in bulk, without consent and without a conversation. Patients have no idea their nomination has changed behind their backs.

Pharmacies who refuse to do this lose business.
Pharmacies who do it gain business.
That isn‚Äôt fair competition. It‚Äôs a broken system.

Bulk switching goes directly against patient choice.
And it punishes the pharmacies who try to do the right thing.

There are only two legitimate scenarios for a bulk nomination change:
‚Ä¢ When a pharmacy is sold
‚Ä¢ When two pharmacies merge
And even then, the NHS manages the change ‚Äî not the PMR system.

Everywhere else, nomination should stay where it belongs:
with the patient.

If you agree this needs to stop, take a stand with us.

üëâ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3YH8boA
posts.name: Bulk nomination is undermining patient choice.

posts.post_caption:
Safy‚Äôs Chemist was losing time every single day.

They were handling 14,500 to 15,000 items a month, and they felt the pace.

Baskets piling up.
Running between rooms.
Checking, bagging and shelving in between appointments.
Back and forth all day.

For Asif, that rhythm felt normal for a busy pharmacy.

Titan changed that completely.

He now spends about an hour in the dispensary across a full day.
Around 85 percent of his time is spent outside it.
The team runs the process.
He can sit with patients.
People mention it in their reviews ‚≠ê

Safety changed as well.
On ProScript, they had five or six near misses a month.
Since moving to Titan, they have had two in an entire year.
Both were human errors, not system issues.

As Asif puts it:
‚ÄúNow I have zero worries. Honestly, it‚Äôs the best thing that‚Äôs happened.‚Äù

His story shows something many pharmacies overlook.
You are losing more time than you think.
Once that changes, everything else follows.

posts.post_caption:
Partial systems create full-scale problems.

Human triage burns people out. Digital triage scales üîÑ

In most pharmacies, people are the system.
They carry the priority üß†

When the system cannot surface what matters, everything turns into ad hoc triage.

One person decides what is urgent.
One person remembers what is next.
One person holds the risk ‚ö†Ô∏è

It works for a while.
Then the volume hits.

Interruptions spike.
Signals get missed.
Fatigue creeps in üòÆ‚Äçüí®

It does not fail instantly.
It fails at scale.

The risk does not disappear.
It lands on the people trying to hold everything together.

And when complexity keeps landing on humans, the cost shows up fast:

‚Ä¢ throughput drops ‚è≥
‚Ä¢ stress climbs üòµ‚Äçüí´
‚Ä¢ confidence slips
‚Ä¢ growth stalls üìâ

You cannot try harder out of this.

You need systems that think before people have to.

When priority and logic live inside the infrastructure, not in someone‚Äôs head, you stop relying on heroics and start building something that can actually scale üí°

See how TITAN removes the hero burden ‚Üí bit.ly/3Nk6VW2

posts.post_caption:
The patient comes first. 

Stop nomination ping-pong.

The NHS Electronic Prescription Service is one of the most advanced prescribing systems in the world. It works because patient nomination is meant to be clear, deliberate, and respected.

But there is a flaw. Some systems can automatically reverse a patient‚Äôs pharmacy nomination, without the patient knowing.

When that happens, prescriptions can bounce between pharmacies. Patients lose clarity about where their medicines are. Trust takes the hit first. And pharmacies playing fair are put at a disadvantage.

At scale, this creates risk for EPS itself. It was not designed for businesses to fight over nominations through automation.

We were asked to build this functionality. We refused. Not because we couldn‚Äôt, but because it breaches our values around patient safety, professional standards, and fair competition.

Patient choice must mean something.

üëâ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3YH8boA

#PatientChoice #EPS #NHSPharmacy #PharmacyEthics #PatientCare #CommunityPharmacy

posts.post_caption:
Most pharmacies hit a ceiling.

At around 4,000 items a month, the team already feels at capacity.
That‚Äôs where Sagar‚Äôs pharmacy started.

Today, they safely process around 17,000 items a month.
And even at that volume, the team stays calm, collected and in control.

The difference is the workflow.

Sagar explains it simply:
‚ÄúTitan AI gives me the right tools to do my clinical checks‚Ä¶ and it saves me time.‚Äù

He runs Titan AI to support those checks, reducing the manual work he used to do every day.

Batch flow streamlines the dispensing process.
And the Kanban view gives a clear audit trail, showing exactly what stage each prescription is at.

The impact?
Sagar now spends around 80% of his time on services instead of checking in the dispensary.

The data tells the story: 4,000 ‚Üí 17,000 items.
A smoother, more organised way of working.

If one pharmacy can scale like this without losing control, the question is simple:

üëâ What is stopping your pharmacy from doing the same?

posts.post_caption:
Independent Prescribing should be the future.

So why will it struggle in 2026?

Every branch is training more IPs. Every policy document points to a more clinical role. But in reality, most pharmacists still start their day the same way they did ten years ago: clearing repeats, chasing stock and firefighting the bench.

Pharmacy First showed the demand is there.
What is missing is capacity.

Training more prescribers cannot overcome a workflow that gives them no time to prescribe.

Until the operational model changes, IP cannot scale.
The bottleneck is not skill. It is time.

üëâ This carousel outlines the problem
üëâ Full breakdown in the blog (link in comments)

#pharmacy #independentprescribing #communitypharmacy #pharmacyfirst #nhs

Stop playing Jenga in pharmacy.

Every owner knows the drill. Chasing baskets. Fixing mis picks. Clearing piles. Checking everything because the system cannot tell you what truly needs you. By the time you look up, half the day has slipped.

posts.post_caption:
Spot the difference. 

The GTIN doesn‚Äôt.

Right now in UK pharmacy, different medicines are arriving with the same GTIN barcode or a GTIN that does not match the product inside.

When that happens, the scanner passes the wrong medicine as correct. Every safety layer collapses.

Pharmacists are forced to slow down, override the check, and carry the risk that should sit with manufacturers and regulators.

This is not a workflow problem. It is a patient safety problem.

The fix is simple:
‚Ä¢ Make accurate GTIN barcodes mandatory
‚Ä¢ Treat incorrect GTINs as labelling errors
‚Ä¢ Protect the final safety check that keeps patients safe

If you work in pharmacy, please add your name.
This is a small action that protects every dispenser in the country.

üëâ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3XNxapM

#EveryPackCounts #PharmacySafety #GTIN #CommunityPharmacy #TitanPMR

posts.post_caption:
Inside Tariq‚Äôs Pharmacy Show Talk.
The message was clear.
Dispensing alone isn‚Äôt enough anymore.

At The Pharmacy Show 2025, Tariq Muhammad shared what many in the room already felt.
The model that once made pharmacy stable is now under strain.

Funding is flat. Volume keeps rising.
But the future isn‚Äôt doom and gloom.
It‚Äôs in taking control.

From TITAN‚Äôs survey of 95 pharmacies:
üìä 86% plan to grow private services.
üìà 59% still want to expand NHS delivery.

Pharmacy‚Äôs direction of travel is clear.
Independent. Efficient. Service-led.

If you missed the talk, this carousel shares the key messages that resonated most.
You can also read the full piece here:
bit.ly/43eKMO2

Book a demo at titanpmr.com
Join the waiting list at titanverse.co.uk

posts.post_caption:
Hub and spoke. Before the law changes.

Medichem Pharmacy shows how.

Most contractors are waiting for October 2025 to see if hub and spoke will work for independents.
But waiting could mean falling behind.

Jeet Vadodaria did not wait.
At Medichem Pharmacy, he built a central hub, connected his four branches with Titan P2P, and reimagined what his team could do.

The results:
‚úÖ Dispensers four times more efficient
‚úÖ 45% less stockholding across branches
‚úÖ Pharmacists free to focus on services
‚úÖ Patients walk into calmer, safer pharmacies

‚ÄúPeer to peer is a brand new tool, which Titan has enabled us to use at the minute. And I think it‚Äôs amazing, because if you are part of the same group, you could technically consider sending your prescriptions to be dispensed at your other branch.‚Äù ‚Äì Jeet Vadodaria

This October, hub and spoke becomes open to every independent.
Medichem proves it can work, safely and profitably, with patients at the centre.

Image text: From 1 Oct 2025, independents can use hubs across ownership lines.
Caption (ally voice):
Here‚Äôs the short version for owners:
‚Ä¢ Law in force: 1 Oct 2025
‚Ä¢ To start: notify your ICB at least 28 days before you begin
‚Ä¢ If you notify on 1 Oct and there is no objection, earliest start is 29 Oct 2025
Checklist: hub due-diligence, SOPs, courier SLAs, business continuity, data sharing, audit trail.
Bottom line: plan now. Put patient safety and resilience first.
CTA: What is the one risk you will mitigate first? Add it below so others can sanity-check their plan.

posts.post_caption:
Sure, Teslas can drive themselves.

But pharmacists cannot swap a pill.

That is where we are in 2025.

Patients are waiting up to three weeks for essential medicines.
Not because shelves are empty.
But because pharmacists are legally blocked from substituting.

The result:
üëâ Patients left untreated
üëâ Surgeries drowning in calls
üëâ Pharmacies stuck in the firing line

The absurdity is obvious.
We trust machines to steer cars through traffic.
But not pharmacists to use their training when a drug is out of stock.

The CCA and others are pushing for substitution rights, deprescribing roles and more front line flexibility. The NHS 10 Year Plan points the same way.

The question is not whether pharmacy is ready.
It is whether the rules will catch up.

#pharmacy #NHS #shortages #patientcare #TitanPMR

posts.post_caption:
In most PMRs, safety depends on signatures and memory.
In Titan, it‚Äôs automatic.

Every script has a full digital audit trail:
‚úÖ Who clinically checked it
‚úÖ When it was labelled
‚úÖ When it was handed out
‚úÖ Who handed it out

No guesswork. No missing scripts. No ‚Äúdid we give that out?‚Äù moments.

For teams, it means less stress and fewer mistakes.
For pharmacists, it means freedom to focus on services.
For patients, it means faster, safer handouts.

That‚Äôs what pharmacy should feel like. Calm. Clear. Accountable.

üëâ Follow us for more ways Titan is changing pharmacy.

#CommunityPharmacy #PharmacyOwner #FutureOfPharmacy #DigitalPharmacy #TitanPMR #AIinHealthcare

posts.post_caption:
üí• What was the Mounjaro Bomb that hit UK pharmacy last week?

Here‚Äôs what really changed üëá

From 1 September, Mounjaro‚Äôs list price jumps by up to 170%.

But the real shock isn‚Äôt just the cost. Pharmacies must now:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Pay the higher price upfront
2Ô∏è‚É£ File monthly rebate reports (splitting NHS vs private)
3Ô∏è‚É£ Wait for retrospective rebates ‚Äî still unclear in detail

For independents running on tight margins, that‚Äôs a cashflow crisis.
For patients, it risks confusion, delays, and unsafe online alternatives.

That‚Äôs why within days, Titan PMR launched a custom reporting suite ‚Äî now used by 1,000+ pharmacies to:
‚úî Generate rebate data in minutes
‚úî Stay compliant without drowning in admin
‚úî Keep the focus on patients, not paperwork

When global shocks land in local pharmacy‚Ä¶
üëâ Titan moves fast.

If dispensing still eats every hour of your day‚Ä¶

Before Titan, she was buried in baskets. Accuracy checks stacked high. End-of-month claims dragging into days. Services struggling to take off.

Now?
Her team runs calmly and confidently:

‚Ä¢ 6,500 items a month

‚Ä¢ 20‚Äì30% faster dispensing with Batch Flow

‚úî 60‚Äì70 BP checks a month (up from 10‚Äì15)
‚úî 18 active weight management clients

posts.post_caption:
Most pharmacy systems were built for paperwork.

Tick boxes. Admin checks. Spreadsheets.

But here‚Äôs the truth:
Clinical pharmacy needs more than admin support.
It needs digital tools that think clinically.

That means:
‚ö° Filtering high-risk items before they reach you
‚ö° Flagging interactions and dose changes in real time
‚ö° Reducing the mental noise so you can focus on people
‚ö° Checking every label, every time
‚ö° Adapting instantly as patients change

If your system isn‚Äôt doing this, it isn‚Äôt clinical-ready.

Pharmacy is moving fast. The tools you choose now will decide whether you keep up ‚Äî or fall behind.

üëâ See the 5 signs in full, then ask: is your digital system really clinical-ready?

posts.post_caption:
Sunshine. Laughter. Basically a school sports day.

Titan BBQ 25 had it all.

Once a year, we get the whole Titan crew together for BBQ 25. A day to swap the laptops for laughter, the deadlines for a bit of good-natured rivalry, and remember what it is like to be properly outside.

ü•• Coconut shy
‚öΩ Football speed tests
üí™ Tug of war
üèÉ Sack races (with some questionable technique)
üçî And food worth queueing twice for

It had all the magic of being back on the school field, just with fewer grazed knees and much better catering.

Thank you to every single one of you for bringing the energy, the humour and the team spirit that made BBQ 25 what it was. You turned it into more than just a day out, you made it a day to remember.

Here is to BBQ 26. Same time next year. Same team.

#TitanBBQ25 #TeamTitan #SummerCelebration

posts.post_caption:
Some pharmacies might walk away from Pharmacy First

And it‚Äôs not hard to see why

New rules mean if you don‚Äôt hit every target, you lose up to ¬£1,000/month

That includes:
‚úî Minor illness consultations
‚úî Contraception services
‚úî Hypertension checks
‚ö†Ô∏è And soon: 1 ABPM per month

The problem?
Only 30% of pharmacies currently meet the full bundle
ABPM is slow, low demand, and hard to convert in a walk-in model
Miss it‚Äîand you lose everything

No flexibility
No partial credit
No margin for real-world pharmacy

This is how NHS dentistry broke
And pharmacy could be next

With pressures this high, more owners are asking:
Should we be focusing on private services instead?

What needs to change before October?
The targets? The model? Or the direction altogether?

Add your voice to the conversation below

Your pharmacy‚Äôs biggest blind spots might be hiding in plain sight. For example:

The Electronic Prescription Service (EPS) is now an industry standard.

But before it existed, people didn‚Äôt know any different.

We accepted the inefficiencies as just part of the job.

At Titan, we see things differently.

Imagine this:

posts.post_caption:
Pharmacies are under pressure.

More demands. Tighter regulations. Less time.

It feels like they're always on the back foot.

The last thing they need is:
Click here. Check there.
Wait. Load.
Error. Repeat.

Every unnecessary step is time lost.

Time that could be spent offering services, delivering care, and making a real difference.

Pharmacy is changing. Workflows need to change too.

That is what The Titan Way is all about. It is not just keeping up with change. It is leading it.

‚Ä¢ Automate repetitive tasks to reduce admin overload.
‚Ä¢ Streamline workflows for faster, simpler processes.
‚Ä¢ Free up pharmacists to focus on services and patient care, not admin.
‚Ä¢ Leverage AI to handle bottlenecks and ensure smooth operations.

Pharmacy is moving forward. Why stay stuck in the past?

üí° What‚Äôs one process in your pharmacy that could be smoother? 

Drop it in the comments.

#PharmacyInnovation #SmarterWorkflows #PharmacyEfficiency #FutureOfPharmacy

A Proud Moment for Titan PMR ‚Äì EPS is Now Fully Rolled Out Across Wales

On 17th November 2023, Titan PMR made history.

Pharmacies can boost revenue and patient care.

Pharmacies in the UK are stepping up as GPs face increasing demand. The upside? Every consultation brings extra NHS income for your pharmacy.

But here‚Äôs the challenge:
Most pharmacy teams are stretched thin managing dispensing and day-to-day operations. To qualify for Pharmacy First consultation payments, you need to handle at least 25 consultations a month.

That‚Äôs where automation and AI make the difference. Tools like Titan streamline workflows, automate admin tasks, and free up your team to focus on patients.

posts.post_caption:
Ever clinically checked a dressing?

Sure you have. 

It‚Äôs not a controlled drug.
Not a risky interaction.
Just‚Ä¶ a dressing.

Not because they‚Äôre dangerous. But because the system doesn‚Äôt know the difference.

Thousands of low-risk items pass through pharmacies every week.
But the system treats them all the same.
So pharmacists are forced to spend time on things that pose almost no risk ‚Äî
just in case.

Smart systems like Titan filter high-risk items first.
Only the safe, low-risk prescriptions‚Äîlike dressings‚Äîgo to AI.
AI that‚Äôs learned from pharmacist decisions and reviews every script in seconds.

So you‚Äôre no longer bogged down by the routine.
You‚Äôre freed to focus on the clinical care that only a human can give.

It‚Äôs not about replacing pharmacists.
It‚Äôs about respecting their time.

It filters the noise.
So pharmacists can focus on what actually matters.

Imagine how different your day could feel ‚Äî
if you weren‚Äôt checking dressings.

posts.idea:
‚ÄúHave you seen the GP yet?‚Äù
‚ÄúNo, I just went to the pharmacy.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the shift. Quiet. Widespread. Already happening.

In July, NHS England released its 10-Year Plan.
Digital-first. AI-enabled. More access, less pressure on GPs.

But here‚Äôs the truth most headlines missed:

Pharmacies aren‚Äôt just helping anymore.
They‚Äôre replacing.

You‚Äôre delivering clinical care at scale.
Not as backup. As the front door.

‚úî Blood pressure checks
‚úî Contraception consultations
‚úî Walk-in assessments for minor illness

What used to be ‚Äúsupporting primary care‚Äù
has become the core of it.


This isn‚Äôt just scope expansion.
It‚Äôs leadership by necessity.


And it‚Äôs time the systems, tools, and recognition caught up.


So if pharmacy is already carrying more,
why are we still treating it like a sideline?


#PrimaryCare #PharmacyFirst #PharmacyLeadership #NHSPlan #ClinicalPharmacy #DigitalHealth

Sticky notes. Paper trays. Colour-coded chaos.


The official workflow of‚Ä¶ every pharmacy trying to scale services on instinct alone.


You start with a few blood pressure checks.
Then contraception. A UTI consultation. Maybe a walk-in earache.


Suddenly, you‚Äôre running a full-blown clinic on post-its.


This is what scaling often feels like:
Messy. Manual. Held together by goodwill and duct tape.


But here‚Äôs the thing no one wants to say:


If pharmacy is going to lead on clinical care ‚Äî
we need infrastructure that‚Äôs built for it.


‚úî Automated booking and referrals
‚úî Clinical records that live in one place
‚úî AI tools that flag issues before they escalate


That‚Äôs how we protect the people doing the work ‚Äî and the patients receiving it.


It‚Äôs not about adding more trays.
It‚Äôs about removing the need for them.

posts.idea:
SLIDE 1 ‚Äî HOOK

Manual checking works.
Until scale makes it unsafe.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 2 ‚Äî THE BEHAVIOUR

Why does manual double-checking exist?

Because verification isn‚Äôt enforced at the point of action.
So people compensate.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 3 ‚Äî THE FAILURE

This works until volume breaks it.

Vigilance degrades faster than workload increases.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 4 ‚Äî THE COST

The cost lands on cognitive load.

Mental energy goes into catching errors
instead of overseeing care.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 5 ‚Äî WHAT FAILS FIRST

Dispensing stability breaks first.

When safety depends on human presence,
scale becomes a risk.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 6 ‚Äî CLOSE

Systems should absorb complexity.
People shouldn‚Äôt.
posts.post_caption:
Manual verification feels responsible.
Until it becomes the bottleneck.

People double-check because the system lets work move forward without confirmation.
That‚Äôs fine at low volume.

At scale, repetition erodes attention.
Safety becomes probabilistic.
And throughput is gated by one human checkpoint.

The cost doesn‚Äôt show up as failure straight away.
It shows up as cognitive load.

Stable dispensing isn‚Äôt about asking people to focus harder.
It‚Äôs about building systems that don‚Äôt rely on focus at all.

Admin is stealing time from patients.

According to the PSNC, 80% of UK pharmacies say staffing and admin pressures are holding back services.

It is not a demand issue.
It is not a training issue.

posts.post_caption:
A Proud Moment for Titan PMR ‚Äì EPS is Now Fully Rolled Out Across Wales

On 17th November 2023, Titan PMR made history.

We became the first PMR to deploy EPS in Wales, with Wellington Road Pharmacy in Rhyl leading the way.

Patients there were the first in Wales to experience a fully digital prescription process.

Now, EPS is fully rolled out across all Titan pharmacies in Wales, marking a major milestone in our mission to transform pharmacy care.

What does this mean for pharmacies?

‚úÖ No more paper prescriptions ‚Üí Fully digital workflow.
‚úÖ Faster, safer dispensing ‚Üí Fewer errors, better stock control.
‚úÖ Less admin, more efficiency ‚Üí Simplified reimbursements & operations.

üí¨ "Visiting Wellington Road Pharmacy, I witnessed firsthand the benefits of the Electronic Prescription Service, which allows GPs to send prescriptions securely online to the patient's choice of community pharmacy, eliminating the need for paper forms."
‚Äî Eluned Morgan MS, Minister for Health and Social Services

üí° This is just the beginning. At Titan PMR, we‚Äôre committed to driving the future of pharmacy innovation.

Only one error in three years.

That doesn‚Äôt happen because people try harder
or check the same thing twice.

It happens when safety is designed into the workflow
so errors are prevented, not just caught.

In Pritee‚Äôs pharmacy, fewer manual steps and clearer system checks

Image text: From 1 Oct 2025, independents can use hubs across ownership lines.
Caption (ally voice):
Here‚Äôs the short version for owners:
‚Ä¢ Law in force: 1 Oct 2025
‚Ä¢ To start: notify your ICB at least 28 days before you begin
‚Ä¢ If you notify on 1 Oct and there is no objection, earliest start is 29 Oct 2025
Checklist: hub due-diligence, SOPs, courier SLAs, business continuity, data sharing, audit trail.

#CommunityPharmacy #PharmacyWorkflow #UKPharmacy #PharmacistLife #DispensaryDesign #PMRSystems #PharmacyInnovation #PrimaryCare #NHSPharmacy
posts.name: You‚Äôre losing 3 hours a day ‚Äî here‚Äôs where it‚Äôs leaking (and how Titan stops it).

posts.post_caption:
Bulk nomination is undermining patient choice.

And it has created a completely unfair playing field.

Some PMR systems allow pharmacies to switch patients back in bulk, without consent and without a conversation. Patients have no idea their nomination has changed behind their backs.

Pharmacies who refuse to do this lose business.
Pharmacies who do it gain business.
That isn‚Äôt fair competition. It‚Äôs a broken system.

Bulk switching goes directly against patient choice.
And it punishes the pharmacies who try to do the right thing.

There are only two legitimate scenarios for a bulk nomination change:
‚Ä¢ When a pharmacy is sold
‚Ä¢ When two pharmacies merge
And even then, the NHS manages the change ‚Äî not the PMR system.

Everywhere else, nomination should stay where it belongs:
with the patient.

If you agree this needs to stop, take a stand with us.

üëâ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3YH8boA

posts.post_caption:
Sticky notes. Paper trays. Colour-coded chaos.


The official workflow of‚Ä¶ every pharmacy trying to scale services on instinct alone.


You start with a few blood pressure checks.
Then contraception. A UTI consultation. Maybe a walk-in earache.


Suddenly, you‚Äôre running a full-blown clinic on post-its.


This is what scaling often feels like:
Messy. Manual. Held together by goodwill and duct tape.


But here‚Äôs the thing no one wants to say:


If pharmacy is going to lead on clinical care ‚Äî
we need infrastructure that‚Äôs built for it.


‚úî Automated booking and referrals
‚úî Clinical records that live in one place
‚úî AI tools that flag issues before they escalate


That‚Äôs how we protect the people doing the work ‚Äî and the patients receiving it.


It‚Äôs not about adding more trays.
It‚Äôs about removing the need for them.


What‚Äôs one workflow hack you wish someone had built years ago?

posts.post_caption:
Spot the difference. 

The GTIN doesn‚Äôt.

Right now in UK pharmacy, different medicines are arriving with the same GTIN barcode or a GTIN that does not match the product inside.

When that happens, the scanner passes the wrong medicine as correct. Every safety layer collapses.

Pharmacists are forced to slow down, override the check, and carry the risk that should sit with manufacturers and regulators.

This is not a workflow problem. It is a patient safety problem.

The fix is simple:
‚Ä¢ Make accurate GTIN barcodes mandatory
‚Ä¢ Treat incorrect GTINs as labelling errors
‚Ä¢ Protect the final safety check that keeps patients safe

If you work in pharmacy, please add your name.
This is a small action that protects every dispenser in the country.

üëâ Sign the petition: bit.ly/3XNxapM

#EveryPackCounts #PharmacySafety #GTIN #CommunityPharmacy #TitanPMR

posts.post_caption:
Safy‚Äôs Chemist was losing time every single day.

They were handling 14,500 to 15,000 items a month, and they felt the pace.

Baskets piling up.
Running between rooms.
Checking, bagging and shelving in between appointments.
Back and forth all day.

For Asif, that rhythm felt normal for a busy pharmacy.

Titan changed that completely.

He now spends about an hour in the dispensary across a full day.
Around 85 percent of his time is spent outside it.
The team runs the process.
He can sit with patients.
People mention it in their reviews ‚≠ê

Safety changed as well.
On ProScript, they had five or six near misses a month.
Since moving to Titan, they have had two in an entire year.
Both were human errors, not system issues.

As Asif puts it:
‚ÄúNow I have zero worries. Honestly, it‚Äôs the best thing that‚Äôs happened.‚Äù

His story shows something many pharmacies overlook.
You are losing more time than you think.
Once that changes, everything else follows.

üìñ Read the full case study ‚Üí http://bit.ly/4sB6bMl

#TitanPMR #PharmacyWorkflow #PharmacySafety #PharmacyInnovation #CommunityPharmacy #IndependentPharmacy

posts.post_caption:
Even the best pharmacies make errors ‚Äî it‚Äôs human nature.
So, how do we reduce the risk?

We train our teams to double-check.
Triple-check.
Stay alert at every step.

But constant vigilance isn‚Äôt sustainable ‚Äî it leads to exhaustion, not excellence.

We often say:
‚ÄúBe careful.‚Äù
‚ÄúDouble-check everything.‚Äù

posts.name: Trustpilot: Hear From Our Customers

posts.idea:
SLIDE 1 ‚Äî HOOK

Manual checking works.
Until scale makes it unsafe.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 2 ‚Äî THE BEHAVIOUR

Why does manual double-checking exist?

Because verification isn‚Äôt enforced at the point of action.
So people compensate.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 3 ‚Äî THE FAILURE

This works until volume breaks it.

Vigilance degrades faster than workload increases.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 4 ‚Äî THE COST

The cost lands on cognitive load.

Mental energy goes into catching errors
instead of overseeing care.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 5 ‚Äî WHAT FAILS FIRST

Dispensing stability breaks first.

When safety depends on human presence,
scale becomes a risk.

‚∏ª

SLIDE 6 ‚Äî CLOSE

Systems should absorb complexity.
People shouldn‚Äôt.
posts.post_caption:
Manual verification feels responsible.
Until it becomes the bottleneck.

People double-check because the system lets work move forward without confirmation.
That‚Äôs fine at low volume.

At scale, repetition erodes attention.
Safety becomes probabilistic.
And throughput is gated by one human checkpoint.

The cost doesn‚Äôt show up as failure straight away.

posts.idea:
Carousel Script (7 slides):
SLIDE 1 (Hook):

¬£158 MILLION CLAWBACK

Announced Dec 23rd.
Two days before Christmas.
Quietly slipped out.

Here's what you need to know.
SLIDE 2 (What is clawback?):

WHAT IS CLAWBACK?

The CPCF sets an "allowed profit envelope" for pharmacy.

If the sector's profit exceeds this level, the government claws it back the following year.

Sounds fair?

Keep reading.
SLIDE 3 (The unfair bit):

HERE'S THE CATCH

Clawback is calculated on the WHOLE INDUSTRY.

Not individual pharmacies.

If Boots makes excess profit, your pharmacy pays too.

Even if you're dispensing at a loss.
SLIDE 4 (The numbers):

THE REALITY

- ¬£16.8m clawed back per quarter
- Starting January 2026

- 60% of owners took no salary in 2024
- ¬£2.6bn funding gap

Independent Prescribing should be the future.

So why will it struggle in 2026?

Every branch is training more IPs. Every policy document points to a more clinical role. But in reality, most pharmacists still start their day the same way they did ten years ago: clearing repeats, chasing stock and firefighting the bench.

Pharmacy First showed the demand is there.
What is missing is capacity.

Training more prescribers cannot overcome a workflow that gives them no time to prescribe.

Until the operational model changes, IP cannot scale.
The bottleneck is not skill. It is time.

posts.idea:
‚ÄúHave you seen the GP yet?‚Äù
‚ÄúNo, I just went to the pharmacy.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the shift. Quiet. Widespread. Already happening.

In July, NHS England released its 10-Year Plan.
Digital-first. AI-enabled. More access, less pressure on GPs.

But here‚Äôs the truth most headlines missed:

Pharmacies aren‚Äôt just helping anymore.
They‚Äôre replacing.

You‚Äôre delivering clinical care at scale.
Not as backup. As the front door.

‚úî Blood pressure checks
‚úî Contraception consultations
‚úî Walk-in assessments for minor illness

What used to be ‚Äúsupporting primary care‚Äù
has become the core of it.

And it‚Äôs time the systems, tools, and recognition caught up.


So if pharmacy is already carrying more,
why are we still treating it like a sideline?

posts.post_caption:
Ever clinically checked a dressing?

Sure you have. 

It‚Äôs not a controlled drug.
Not a risky interaction.
Just‚Ä¶ a dressing.

Not because they‚Äôre dangerous. But because the system doesn‚Äôt know the difference.

Thousands of low-risk items pass through pharmacies every week.
But the system treats them all the same.
So pharmacists are forced to spend time on things that pose almost no risk ‚Äî
just in case.

Smart systems like Titan filter high-risk items first.
Only the safe, low-risk prescriptions‚Äîlike dressings‚Äîgo to AI.
AI that‚Äôs learned from pharmacist decisions and reviews every script in seconds.

So you‚Äôre no longer bogged down by the routine.
You‚Äôre freed to focus on the clinical care that only a human can give.

It‚Äôs not about replacing pharmacists.
It‚Äôs about respecting their time.

It filters the noise.
So pharmacists can focus on what actually matters.

Imagine how different your day could feel ‚Äî
if you weren‚Äôt checking dressings.

What‚Äôs one thing you wish you had more time for?

posts.name: Rahul: Puri Pharmacy‚Äôs Transformation

posts.post_caption:
Sure, Teslas can drive themselves.

But pharmacists cannot swap a pill.

That is where we are in 2025.

Patients are waiting up to three weeks for essential medicines.
Not because shelves are empty.
But because pharmacists are legally blocked from substituting.

The result:
üëâ Patients left untreated
üëâ Surgeries drowning in calls
üëâ Pharmacies stuck in the firing line

The absurdity is obvious.
We trust machines to steer cars through traffic.
But not pharmacists to use their training when a drug is out of stock.

The CCA and others are pushing for substitution rights, deprescribing roles and more front line flexibility. The NHS 10 Year Plan points the same way.

The question is not whether pharmacy is ready.
It is whether the rules will catch up.

#pharmacy #NHS #shortages #patientcare #TitanPMR
posts.name: 3 Weeks No Meds

posts.post_caption:
Some pharmacies might walk away from Pharmacy First

And it‚Äôs not hard to see why

New rules mean if you don‚Äôt hit every target, you lose up to ¬£1,000/month

That includes:
‚úî Minor illness consultations
‚úî Contraception services
‚úî Hypertension checks
‚ö†Ô∏è And soon: 1 ABPM per month

The problem?
Only 30% of pharmacies currently meet the full bundle
ABPM is slow, low demand, and hard to convert in a walk-in model
Miss it‚Äîand you lose everything

No flexibility
No partial credit
No margin for real-world pharmacy

This is how NHS dentistry broke
And pharmacy could be next

With pressures this high, more owners are asking:
Should we be focusing on private services instead?

What needs to change before October?
The targets? The model? Or the direction altogether?

Add your voice to the conversation below

#PharmacyFirst #CommunityPharmacy #PharmacyFunding #ABPM #PharmacyServices #PharmacyPressure #FutureOfPharmacy #TitanPMR
